Motivation=expectancy*value/impulsiveness*delay

1 – Whether you’re trying to lose 20 pounds, get that promotion at work or quit smoking, sticking to your goal isn’t an easy task. After all, 45% of people drop their New Year’s Resolutions after a month. So why is it so difficult to keep motivated and how can science help us achieve what we’re after?

2 – In one MIT study, students were given two types of tasks. In the first, they had to hit two keys on a keyboard as many times as possible in four minutes and those that did it the fastest would receive money. For some, the reward was $300 while for others only $30.

3 – Interestingly, performance was 95% greater in the high $300 group, highlighting how money can be a motivator. But in the second task, the same students were asked to solve a more complex math problem and this time, those offered the high reward performed 32% slower than the small reward group.

Then they are often setting the goals too high, similar to the other extreme of doing something wrong like drinking the large soda and then eating the large ice cream. The problem here is not ACCEPTING MISTAKES, cause reality is different than our imagination and we are always doing mistakes so that we can improve. I think every individual is perfect; it's just our beliefs and expectations that lead us to think that we are not perfect, because we do mistakes. But that actually is a property that makes us perfect, cause we learn from it.

Stop giving yourself a choice. Put yourself in a position with no choices like I do.. then you don't need what I call "forced motivation".

I can't stand the typical forced motivation of the everyday run of thr mill new years resolutionist. humans are far too monkey-like.. too curious.. far too easily bored and far too clever .. too fickle to just stick to doing the same thing forever.

We need constant changes and challenges to stay mentally satisfied and motivated. So either make your goals fun to work on or give yourself absolutely no choice and you'll end up happier either way.

Something I'd like to add, I've found two method good for sticking to a resolution or goal.
1) Break it down into smaller steps. Trying to eat healthier? I started by just keeping a record of what I ate, without intentionally changing what I was eating. Then, with a baseline (sort of, I think the act of monitoring change my eating habits too) I could pick small changes. A little less cooking oil here, fish instead of beef for dinner, less milk more soy, etc.
2) Replace a bad habit with a new habit that mimics the bad one (or at least keeps your mind off of it. I quit smoking by learning how to juggle. When I got a craving, I'd go outside and juggle for a few minutes. I got a short break, got to go outside, and the juggling kept my hands and mind busy. It's wasn't a perfect solution by itself, but it did help in quitting.

Steps to complete your goals:
1. Define your goal as clearly and realistically as you can, and write it down.
2. Define small steps you can actually do every day, to eventually accomplish your goal, and write them all down.
3. Every time you make a small step, check it off of your written list of steps.
4. Revise your plan when needed.
5. When your list is about halfway checked off, go back to step 1 and write down a new goal that is dependant on the previous goal. and start the process again.
If you feel overwhelmed, remember that you can always have many different goals, and take small steps towards each of them, with overlap.
